Sorry, HMAC-MD5 is the only usable digest in RKAP. If we deprecated it, we'd have to come up with a new digest (HMAC-SHA256 probably). This would have to be implemented, go through interop, probably go back to another WGLC etc.

comments.author: tomaszmrugalski
comments.body:
> Just curious, why is RKAP just defined for Reconfigure?

R in RKAP stands for Reconfigure. It was intended only for Reconfigure. I suppose the server could use it for every REPLY (except when responding to REBIND). No sure what were the exact reasons, but I can speculate. Perhaps because it wouldn't work for REBIND? Or many clients not supporting it at all and doing fine? So how effective would it be - "some clients that support it get the transactions protected some of the time". That doesn't sound very reassuring.

RKAP is not great. When supported, the message sent in the initial exchange sends Rekonfigure key in plain text. No Diffie-Hellman or anything similar. Plain text over wire. So there's a window of opportunity, where sniffing attack is very easy. We tried to solve this (see https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-dhc-sedhcpv6/), but we gave up after -21 and getting conflicting directions from different IESG members.

I'll add a note when addressing #44.
